summary: At Captain Marvel I literally said to my mom “Wow this is the first Marvel movie I’ve gone to where people haven’t left before...
body: At Captain Marvel I literally said to my mom “Wow this is the first Marvel movie I’ve gone to where people haven’t left before the post-credits scenes.” Then 70% of the theater proceeded to leave after the first scene. I can say (no spoilers, I promise) that they missed one heck of a hairball.

reblog.comment: At Captain Marvel I literally said to my mom “Wow this is the first Marvel movie I’ve gone to where people haven’t left before the post-credits scenes.” Then 70% of the theater proceeded to leave after the first scene. I can say (no spoilers, I promise) that they missed one heck of a hairball.

summary: Get to know her: big screen heroines
title: Get to know her: big screen heroines
body:
Now that Carol, Diana and others got their movies, you might be interested to check out their comics. Unfortunately, 90% of comics is crap. Fortunately, there’s somebody who has read a lot of comics and can point to storylines that are jewels – namely, me. Let’s go!

Captain Marvel

Carol’s been around for a while, but unfortunately her comics tended to be on the bad end of the continuum. That’s why the comics here are recent.

The Life of Captain Marvel (2018 series) presents Carol’s revised origin, so it is a good start, especially since it’s only 5 chapters.

Captain Marvel Vol 9 features Carol as a chief of a space station in charge of protecting Earth from space threats. Second storyline ties into “Civil War II”, but all the knowledge needed to understand the context can be found in its Wikipedia entry 10 chapters.

Ultimates Vol 2 & Ultimates 2 Vol 2 (concluded in Ultimates #100) has Carol as a member of titular group of superpowered individuals tackling threats of cosmic scale. 22 chapters total.

A-Force Vol 1 & 2 has Carol as a member of an all-female superheroine team. 15 chapters total.

Captain Marvel and the Carol Corps is an AU series in which Carol is a part of an all-female group of aviators. The women realize they have been lied to about their world when Carol discovers a shipwreck survivor. 5 chapters.

Wonder Woman

Diana comes in three flavors: Original Fanservice (prior to Crisis on Infinite Earth and in Earth One series), Reimagined For Modern Audience (most known version), and Darker And Edgier version. I will focus on the Reimagined Diana, with small nod to Sexy and Dark Dianas.

Wonder Woman Vol 2 1-14 features Diana’s origin story, early adventures in modern world, first meeting with her archenemies Ares and Cheetah, as well as a mythology-inspired adventure that deepens the series’ lore.

Wonder Woman 600-614 features Diana in an alternate universe in which Themiscira was long destroyed and the Amazons were in hiding, hunted one after another. Diana strives to return to her original World.

Wonder Woman: Amazonia is a single volume AU in the spiring of Handmaiden, in which women are slaves to men and have no rights. Diana rebels against the system.

Wonder Woman: Earth One is a two volume Fanservicy reimagining of Wonder Woman. First volume is basically a condensed retelling of early WW chapters. The story is notable for having a beautiful art.

Black Widow

Natasha has a surprising number of well written storylines dedicated to her. The reading order provided below gives the best reading experience.

Black Widow Vol 5 19-20 provides a glimpse into Natasha’s unsavory past.

Black Widow Vol 1, Vol 2, Vol 3 & Black Widow 2 are a spy/action story flowing from one adventure to another, introducing Yelena Belova, another girl from the Red Room. 18 chapters total.

Bonus: Black Widow: Pale Little Spider follows Yelena on a “sexy” adventure after she finds her trainer died during a bdsm session. Better than it sounds! 3 chapters.

Note: I stopped paying attention to the character’s adventures in 2016, so I’m unaware of any recent developments.

Scarlet Witch

Comics Wanda is very different from MCU Wanda, and most of her appearances are better to be forgotten. There are however two interesting series.

Avengers: Children’s Crusade features Wanda’s father, brother and sons searching for her after she disappeared from face of Earth. May be confusing for readers coming with knowledge of MCU only. 10 chapters.

Scarlet Witch Vol 2 has Wanda as sort of world travelling mystical detective. 15 chapters.

The Wasp

The Wasp actually refers to several different characters. There’s mainstream Janet, notoriously underused, whose first prominent moments are being punched by her husband, dying in a battle, and running for her life while romancing Wonder Man in a weird AU timeline that was eventually erased. There’s Hope, a villain from a future timeline. There’s Nadia, teen Hungarian-Russian girl trained by the Red Room (she is less awesome than it sounds). And then there’s Ultimate Wasp, definitely the most developed of the characters, but also one staring in the unsavory mature audience Ultimates.

Ultimates are Avengers, but Darker and Edgier. In this incarnation, Janet is Chinese-American mutant and victim of spousal abuse. The series features also unsympathetic reinterpretations of Black Widow and Scarlet Witch. Early storylines are interesting when you like this type of storytelling, though. I recommend Ultimates Vol 1, Ultimates 2 Vol 1, and Ultimates Annual #2, 27 chapters total.

Others

Alias #22-28 feature the origin of Jessica Jones and her rematch against Purple Man. Since 2016, there’s been an ongoing series by Jessica’s creator, called simply Jessica Jones, but I’m unfamiliar with it.

Journey Into Mystery #646-655 feature adventures of Lady Sif.

Fearless Defenders #1-12 feature an all-female team including Valkyrie and Moonstar from upcoming New Mutans movie. The story explores Valkyrie’s origin.

Exiles Vol 3 #1-12 features a team of reality sliding heroes, including Blink, Valkyrie, and Ms Marvel.

Peggy Carter appears in three one shots: Captain America and the First Thirteen, Captain America: Peggy Carter, Agent of S.H.I.E.L.D. , and Agent Carter: S.H.I.E.L.D. 50th Anniversary #1
body_abstract: Now that Carol, Diana and others got their movies, you might be interested to check out their comics. Unfortunately, 90% of comics is crap. Fortunately, there’s somebody who has read a lot of comics and can point to storylines that are jewels – namely, me. Let’s go!

Black Widow Vol 5 19-20 provides a glimpse into Natasha’s unsavory past.

Black Widow Vol 1, Vol 2, Vol 3 & Black Widow 2 are a spy/action story flowing from one adventure to another, introducing Yelena Belova, another girl from the Red Room. 18 chapters total.

Bonus: Black Widow: Pale Little Spider follows Yelena on a “sexy” adventure after she finds her trainer died during a bdsm session. Better than it sounds! 3 chapters.

Note: I stopped paying attention to the character’s adventures in 2016, so I’m unaware of any recent developments.

Scarlet Witch

Comics Wanda is very different from MCU Wanda, and most of her appearances are better to be forgotten. There are however two interesting series.

Avengers: Children’s Crusade features Wanda’s father, brother and sons searching for her after she disappeared from face of Earth. May be confusing for readers coming with knowledge of MCU only. 10 chapters.

Scarlet Witch Vol 2 has Wanda as sort of world travelling mystical detective. 15 chapters.

The Wasp

The Wasp actually refers to several different characters. There’s mainstream Janet, notoriously underused, whose first prominent moments are being punched by her husband, dying in a battle, and running for her life while romancing Wonder Man in a weird AU timeline that was eventually erased. There’s Hope, a villain from a future timeline. There’s Nadia, teen Hungarian-Russian girl trained by the Red Room (she is less awesome than it sounds). And then there’s Ultimate Wasp, definitely the most developed of the characters, but also one staring in the unsavory mature audience Ultimates.

Ultimates are Avengers, but Darker and Edgier. In this incarnation, Janet is Chinese-American mutant and victim of spousal abuse. The series features also unsympathetic reinterpretations of Black Widow and Scarlet Witch. Early storylines are interesting when you like this type of storytelling, though. I recommend Ultimates Vol 1, Ultimates 2 Vol 1, and Ultimates Annual #2, 27 chapters total.

Others

Alias #22-28 feature the origin of Jessica Jones and her rematch against Purple Man. Since 2016, there’s been an ongoing series by Jessica’s creator, called simply Jessica Jones, but I’m unfamiliar with it.

Journey Into Mystery #646-655 feature adventures of Lady Sif.

Fearless Defenders #1-12 feature an all-female team including Valkyrie and Moonstar from upcoming New Mutans movie. The story explores Valkyrie’s origin.

Exiles Vol 3 #1-12 features a team of reality sliding heroes, including Blink, Valkyrie, and Ms Marvel.

Peggy Carter appears in three one shots: Captain America and the First Thirteen, Captain America: Peggy Carter, Agent of S.H.I.E.L.D. , and Agent Carter: S.H.I.E.L.D. 50th Anniversary #1
trail.content:
Now that Carol, Diana and others got their movies, you might be interested to check out their comics. Unfortunately, 90% of comics is crap. Fortunately, there’s somebody who has read a lot of comics and can point to storylines that are jewels – namely, me. Let’s go!

Captain Marvel

Carol’s been around for a while, but unfortunately her comics tended to be on the bad end of the continuum. That’s why the comics here are recent.

The Life of Captain Marvel (2018 series) presents Carol’s revised origin, so it is a good start, especially since it’s only 5 chapters.

Captain Marvel Vol 9 features Carol as a chief of a space station in charge of protecting Earth from space threats. Second storyline ties into “Civil War II”, but all the knowledge needed to understand the context can be found in its Wikipedia entry 10 chapters.

Ultimates Vol 2 & Ultimates 2 Vol 2 (concluded in Ultimates #100) has Carol as a member of titular group of superpowered individuals tackling threats of cosmic scale. 22 chapters total.

A-Force Vol 1 & 2 has Carol as a member of an all-female superheroine team. 15 chapters total.

Captain Marvel and the Carol Corps is an AU series in which Carol is a part of an all-female group of aviators. The women realize they have been lied to about their world when Carol discovers a shipwreck survivor. 5 chapters.

Wonder Woman

Diana comes in three flavors: Original Fanservice (prior to Crisis on Infinite Earth and in Earth One series), Reimagined For Modern Audience (most known version), and Darker And Edgier version. I will focus on the Reimagined Diana, with small nod to Sexy and Dark Dianas.

Wonder Woman Vol 2 1-14 features Diana’s origin story, early adventures in modern world, first meeting with her archenemies Ares and Cheetah, as well as a mythology-inspired adventure that deepens the series’ lore.

Wonder Woman 600-614 features Diana in an alternate universe in which Themiscira was long destroyed and the Amazons were in hiding, hunted one after another. Diana strives to return to her original World.

Wonder Woman: Amazonia is a single volume AU in the spiring of Handmaiden, in which women are slaves to men and have no rights. Diana rebels against the system.

Wonder Woman: Earth One is a two volume Fanservicy reimagining of Wonder Woman. First volume is basically a condensed retelling of early WW chapters. The story is notable for having a beautiful art.

Black Widow

Natasha has a surprising number of well written storylines dedicated to her. The reading order provided below gives the best reading experience.

Black Widow Vol 5 19-20 provides a glimpse into Natasha’s unsavory past.

Black Widow Vol 1, Vol 2, Vol 3 & Black Widow 2 are a spy/action story flowing from one adventure to another, introducing Yelena Belova, another girl from the Red Room. 18 chapters total.

Bonus: Black Widow: Pale Little Spider follows Yelena on a “sexy” adventure after she finds her trainer died during a bdsm session. Better than it sounds! 3 chapters.

Note: I stopped paying attention to the character’s adventures in 2016, so I’m unaware of any recent developments.

Scarlet Witch

Comics Wanda is very different from MCU Wanda, and most of her appearances are better to be forgotten. There are however two interesting series.

Avengers: Children’s Crusade features Wanda’s father, brother and sons searching for her after she disappeared from face of Earth. May be confusing for readers coming with knowledge of MCU only. 10 chapters.

Scarlet Witch Vol 2 has Wanda as sort of world travelling mystical detective. 15 chapters.

The Wasp

The Wasp actually refers to several different characters. There’s mainstream Janet, notoriously underused, whose first prominent moments are being punched by her husband, dying in a battle, and running for her life while romancing Wonder Man in a weird AU timeline that was eventually erased. There’s Hope, a villain from a future timeline. There’s Nadia, teen Hungarian-Russian girl trained by the Red Room (she is less awesome than it sounds). And then there’s Ultimate Wasp, definitely the most developed of the characters, but also one staring in the unsavory mature audience Ultimates.

Ultimates are Avengers, but Darker and Edgier. In this incarnation, Janet is Chinese-American mutant and victim of spousal abuse. The series features also unsympathetic reinterpretations of Black Widow and Scarlet Witch. Early storylines are interesting when you like this type of storytelling, though. I recommend Ultimates Vol 1, Ultimates 2 Vol 1, and Ultimates Annual #2, 27 chapters total.

Others

Alias #22-28 feature the origin of Jessica Jones and her rematch against Purple Man. Since 2016, there’s been an ongoing series by Jessica’s creator, called simply Jessica Jones, but I’m unfamiliar with it.

Journey Into Mystery #646-655 feature adventures of Lady Sif.

Fearless Defenders #1-12 feature an all-female team including Valkyrie and Moonstar from upcoming New Mutans movie. The story explores Valkyrie’s origin.

Exiles Vol 3 #1-12 features a team of reality sliding heroes, including Blink, Valkyrie, and Ms Marvel.
